title: 104_hr1114
content: AUTHORITY FOR 16- AND 17-YEAR-OLDS TO LOAD MATERIALS INTO SCRAP PAPER BALERS AND PAPER BOX COMPACTORS. Section 13(c) of the Fair Labor Standards Act allows 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards. They are not permitted to operate or unload the materials. 16- and 17-year-old employees can load scrap paper balers and paper box compactors if they meet safety standards set by the American National Standards Institute. The machines must have an on-off switch with a key-lock controlled by employees. The scrap paper balers and paper box compactors must meet safety standards set by the American National Standards Institute. The machines should have an on-off switch with a key-lock controlled by employees aged 18 or older. The switch must be kept in the off position when the machines are not in use, and a notice must be posted stating that 16- and 17-year-old employees can only load the machines. The employer must provide notice that 16- and 17-year-old employees can only load scrap paper balers and paper box compactors, and those under 18 cannot operate or unload them. The Secretary will publish safety standards for these machines, and employers must report any injuries to employees under 18 to the Secretary. Employers must report any injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors to the Secretary for safety evaluation. Employers are required to report injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors to the Secretary for safety evaluation. The reports must include details such as employer and employee information, incident date, injury description, and how the incident occurred. These reports are used to assess the impact of safety measures on children's safety. Employers must report injuries or fatalities of employees under 18 involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors to the Secretary within 10 days. The report should include details like employer and employee information, incident date, injury description, and equipment involved. The Secretary cannot solely rely on these reports to determine violations of child labor laws. The Secretary must conduct an investigation and inspection before determining violations of child labor laws related to injuries or deaths of employees under 18 involving scrap paper balers or paper box compactors. Reporting requirements expire 2 years after enactment. SEC. 2 amends the Fair Labor Standards Act by including section 13(c)(5) in civil money penalties. SEC. 3 clarifies that apprentices and student learners' exemption in section 570.63 of title 29 CFR is unaffected.
